A Tetradrachm of Maximian (radiate) (286-294) Reverse: Uncertain Reference: Uncertain. A single coin found during building operations at Llangwm in 1973.

Killibury, or Kelly Rounds, is an Iron Age camp. No coins have been found there, but on 17 August 1921, Mr A. L. Hoskin and two other youths, found coins in a trench about two feet deep dug by workmen at the back of a cattle-shed at Sandylands farm. The coins include a bronze coin of Carthage, Zeugitana, north Africa, Roman imperial coins and one billon tetradrachm of Alexandria, all of which were presented to the Royal Institution of Cornwall in 1979. The strange association must comprise a modern loss.

A billon tetradrachm (22 mm) in good condition, in Bodmin Museum, said to be from the camp, is either a modern loss or, more likely, from some other locality, perhaps not even Cornwall. Mint of Alexandria. AD 270. Curtis 1695.
Mrs C. Reynolds dug up in the garden at No. 70 in 1986 the following tetradrachm (19 mm).
Cornwall. Stony Bridge, parish of Tywardreath (found in old stream tin- works). 1928. Aurelian?

An Alexandrian bronze coin of Diocletian dated to AD.284-5, was found with a very worn copper penny in the back garden of 48 Swinton Drive, Glasgow SW 2, in or before January, 1948 at a depth of two feet. It is not known whether the soil was undisturbed for the house-building of the then new housing scheme, or even whether the soil was introduced from another source

A copper alloy Roman provincial billon tetradrachm of Probus dating to the period AD 281 - 282 (Reece period 14). Reverse type depiciting eagle standing left, head right with wreath in beak flanked by the letters L Z. Mint of Alexandria. See BMC Alexandria, p. 315, no. 2431.

A small package brought into HM had written on it, 'Coins dug up near Alexandria, Oct. 1914' and contained two Scottish communion tokens and one Roman coin: Nero debased tetradrachm AD 64-5 Alexandria (W/13-39g/0/HM). It may be that the Alexandria referred to is that in Egypt where the coin was minted but the association with the communion tokens would argue against this.

In May 1934, Mr J Nairn, Braidwood, Carluke, sent to the writer for identification two coins which he had thrown up when digging in the orchard. They were both of Diocletian, and had been minted at Alexandria. An inquiry as to the depth at which they were lying elicited no response, thus there is the possibility that they were recent importations, thrown aside as valueless. May be among collection of finds at Fairholm, near Larkhall (NS75 51).. Alexandrian coin (found with another digging in an orchard). First regnal year. Hope on reverse. PSAS 1939 p 244
Alexandrian coin (found with another digging in an orchard). Fifth regnal year. Eusebia on reverse. PSAS 1939 p 244

Three Roman coins were found sometime before 1977 on land between Fernhill Road and Windsor Road, Bootle. The coins were said to have been found a few yards apart. They were all Alexandrian issues, one of Maximian (reverse with Elpis), one of Probus (reverse with eagle) and one of Domitian (reverse with Dikaiosyne). (1-2) The Domitian identification could be an error for Diocletian, which would bring the dates of the three coins together.

A billion tetradrachm of Philip I (AD 244-249) was found in the area of what is now Fulwood Drive, Toxteth Park. The coin was brought to the museum on 21st September 1975. The field was then recently levelled having been previously a very irregular and hilly golf course. The coin could have come from an area of infilling. (1)

A considerable number of coins have been found in recent years around an evident earthwork, known as Burrow Heights, which lies about three miles south of the Roman fortsite and is adjacent to the line of the Roman road from Walton-le-Dale to Lancaster; a possible interpretation of the site was proposed some years ago by B. J. N. Edwards (in Transactions of the Cumberland and Westmorland Antiquarian and Archaeological Society, LXXI (1971), pp. 27-32). One of the coins is an Alexandrian tetradrachm of Hadrian (Milne 968, of A.D. 121 2). The other coins are Roman imperial issues.[9 coins. Latest is Claudius II. see article]. Although the sample is small, its make-up is suggestive of a military source; if so, the site may have been a watchtower, situated by the side of the road.
fairly worn Alexandrian coin. Found lying on the ground in the garden of Mann's Buildings. Unclear if it had been there long or not. PSAS 51-60 p 138

Alexandrian billon tetradrachm (i.e. a base silver 4 drachma coin struck in Alexandria in Egypt). These coins were issued under the Roman emperors for (roughly) the first 3 centuries AD, getting progressively baser and smaller. These coins usually have the bust of an emperor (occasionally a wife or son) on the obverse and assorted Classical or Egyptianising themes on the reverse. They exist because the emperors treated Egypt like a private estate and it kept its own currency system right through to the 290's
Alexandrian billon coin struck in second year of Diocletian's reign. PSAS 1924 p. 327. Dikaiosyne on reverse. Dug up in garden.

Tetradrachm of Alexandria, probably 3rd century, included in a list if finds reported to Birmingham City Museum in 1977. Recovered from the River Severn in Quarry Park. - Shropshire Archaeological Society Newsletter 8, 1978, 9 (R Taylor)

These coins usually have the bust of an emperor (occasionally a wife or son) on the obverse and assorted Classical or Egyptianising themes on the reverse. They exist because the emperors treated Egypt like a private estate and it kept its own currency system right through to the 290's

The coin is in a slightly worn but good condition.Ref: Milne, J, G, 1971, ?University of Oxford Ashmolean Museum: Catalogue of Alexandrian Coins?, page 7, ref no 238.

A copper-alloy Roman provincial coin, probably a tetradrachm (or similar) of Hadrian (AD 117-138) or possibly Trajan (AD 98-117), dating to the period c.AD 117-138 (Reece period 6). Reverse type depicting Zeus standing left holding vertical sceptre, an eagle at his feet left(?). Mint of Alexandria. This is a large Roman provincial bronze coin struck at the mint of Alexandria. It's patina, combined with its findspot in a garden several years ago, suggest it is quite possible this is not an ancient loss.

A complete struck/ hammered copper alloy billian tetradrachm, minted in Alexandria, Egypt by Probus during the second regnal year of his reign between AD 276-7 (diameter: 19.5mm; thickness: 4mm; weight: 6.7g). The coin is in a slightly worn but good condition.Ref: Milne, J, G, 1933, 'University of Oxford: Ashmolean Museum: Catalogue of Alexandrian Coins', page 109, ref nos 4539-4544 (particularly ref no 4540).

Findspot: Cornholme Working Men's Club, Todmorden (1964-5). Found during gravelling outside Cornholme Working Men's Club, Todmorden. Gravel believed to have come from York area. Rev: Athena seated left holding, in her left hand, a Victory carrying a wreath and, in her right hand, a sceptre. L H dates the coin to AD 291-292, the seventh year of Diocletian's reign.

A copper alloy Roman coin; a Tetradrachm of Diocletian (AD 284-305) dating from AD 285-286. Pax standing on reverse. Mint of Alexandria. Compare NCL-AE9AE1 which is the same type of coin and cites BMC Greek, Alexandria, p. 2493 var; Curtis, The Tetradrachms of Roman Egypt p. 164, no. 1976; and Milne, Catalogue of Alexandridan Coins, p. 114, no. 4774.

A complete copper alloy, Roman, Tetradrachum of Claudius II Gothicus (AD 268 - AD 270). Uncertain reverse type, depicting an Eagle right, head turned left with wreath in beak, dating to Year I of Claudius II reign, AD 268 - AD 269 (Reece Period: 13). Mint of Alexandria. Milne (1933), page 101, No 4225, or Christiansen (1991), page 101, No 3358 or 3359.Diameter: 21.5 mmThickness: 4.9 mmWeight: 10.5 gRefMilne, J, G, 1933, 'Catalogue of Alexandrian Coins in the Ashmolean Museum', Oxford University Press, LondonChristiansen, E (1991) 'Coins of Alexandria and the Nomes' British Museum Occasional Paper 77, British Museum Trustees, London

A billon tetradrachma of Maximianus I (286-295 A.D.) unearthed about 1960 in an allotment garden on the Grassington Road just opposite Skipton Castle by Mr. Herbert Mason was brought to the Cartwright Museum Mr Forder says that the coin was found in the Rosebank Nurseries owned by Mr Mason and formerly centred at SD 98515224. (2) - MONUMENT NO. 46531"
billon tetradrachm of Gallienus probably found at Corstopitum (Corbridge)
Uppermill. Found near Ballgrove by Mr J. F. Buckley c. 1930. Probus. Ad 276-282. Billon Tetradrachm. coin in private hands.
Castleshaw Valley
A tetradrachm of Diocletian, probably found on a sand-bank in the river.
Two Roman copper coins of Diocletian, a follis and a smaller coin minted in Alexandria, were found in a lump of hard earth in Sutton Park close to Icknield Street in 1909.

Monument no 1756. Denarius of L.Procilius (78-77 B.C.) Condition fair - plated silver bronze. Billon tetradrachm of Maximianus I (A.D. 286-295) Condition fair. Minted in Alexandria. It is unclear from the old WYAS SMR card whether or not these coins were found together. Found when digging the foundations for Whin's Cottage, Micklethwaite, in 1940

Mon. No 1824. Billon tetradrachm of Nero (A.D. 54-68.) Dug up in a garden in Edgerton prior to 1927. Find spot unknown; grid ref. centred on Edgerton. Present location unknown; supposed to be in the Tolson Memorial Museum, but in 1964 the Museum had no record of this coin.

Base metal tetradrachm of Diocletian, Greek mint of Alexandria, A.D. 296. Found in 1948 in a garden of Highfield M No 1850. Crescent. Exact find spot unknown; grid ref. centred on the garden of the house in Highfield Crescent belonging to the finder. In Cartwright Memorial Hall Museum, acc. no. NH 43.50. Of the same type as the coins from Bolton Wood also in the Cartwright Memorial Hall Museum.
Tetradrachm of Diocletian (A.D.284-304.) Found in 1950 in the garden of 21 Moorhead Terrace, a few inches below the surface. In Cartwright Memorial Hall Museum, acc. no. 12.51.
Billon tetradrachm of Diocletian (A.D. 284-304.) Found in 1936 in an allotment garden at Four Land Ends. In Cartwright Memorial Hall Museum, acc. no. A13/56.

Billon Tetradrachm of Diocletian (A.D. 284-295.) Obverse: Greek inscription; laureate bust wearing cuirass. Reverse: Eirene standing left, holds ears of corn and sceptre; in field, LS. Mint of Alexandria. Condition: Fair. Found 30 April 1953, under a stone in the grounds of St. Bede's Grammar School, Heaton, Bradford. Present location unknown.
Possible As/Dupondius but could be an Alexandrian Tetradrachm. Its thickness and bevelled edge are both in keeping with this identification.

Billon tetradrachm of Maximianus I (A.D. 284-295.) Mint of Alexandria. Found circa 1936 in an allotment garden in Legrams Lane. Exact find spot unknown; grid ref. centred on allotment gardens. In Cartwright Memorial Hall Museum, acc. no. A22-58.
Billon tetradrachm of Claudius II Gothicus (A.D. 268-270.) Found circa 1930 in a garden at 17 Watty Road. Present location unknown.

An Alexandian billon tetradrachm of Diocletian (284-305), regnal year 5 (AD288/9). Obverse: Bust facing right. Reverse: Eusabia standing left, wearing veil, dropping incense from right hand on altar, left hand wrapped in peplos. To left L, to right E (epsilon). Coin reference: Milne, 1971, p.117, no. 4896.
Tetradrachm of Diocletian (A.D. 284-305.) Mint of Alexandria, A.D. 291. Found circa 1900. Find spot unconfirmed. In Cartwright Memorial Hall Museum, acc. no. NH 37-50.

Billon tetradrachm of Aurelian and Daballathus (A.D. 271-272.) Found prior to 1964 on a building site in Bradford. Exact find spot unknown; grid ref. centred on Bradford. In Cartwright Memorial Hall Museum.
Billon tetradrachm of Diocletian (A.D. 284-295.) Found prior to 1958 in the garden of 37 Sandford Road, Bradford Moor, at a depth of six inches. Present location unknown.
A Roman bronze coin of Maximillian (AD 285-96), from the mint at Alexandria, was found at Esholt circa 1910, on the site of the Esholt sewage works. A replica of the coin is in Cartwight Hall Museum.
Provincial coin struck in Egypt for the Roman emperor Commodus. Made from billon (base silver). This is a tetradrachm.
Staffordshire. Burton-on-Trent. 1928. Diocletian. Rev . Elpis, year 6
Copper alloy Alexandrian tetradrachm. Reference: SNG Copenhagen 941-942.

A tetradrachm of Aurelian (AD273) from Alexandria found in a field to the W of Halford Old Bridge. - record number MWA2295 (beside Fosse Way). Findspot - a Roman coin was found 200m south west of the church at Halford"
A Roman Greek imperial copper alloy tetradahcm of Probus, dating to AD 276-282. Probably mint of Alexandria.
A Roman Greek imperial copper alloy tetradahcm, probably of Probus, probably dating to AD 276-282. Probably mint of Alexandria.
A Roman Greek imperial copper alloy tetradachm of Probus, dating to AD 279. Reverse depicting Eirene standing left, to left L. Mint of Alexandria. cf. Milne 4550.
A Roman Greek imperial copper alloy tetradachm of Diocletian, dating to AD 294-300. Reverse depicting Nike advancing right holding wreath, L to left. Mint of Alexandria.
1 Tetradrachma. From Alexandria. Probus (276-282 AD) minted in 277 AD. Found in a garden in St Mary's Road, Leamington, and brought in as an enquiry in 1965.k. HER Number: MWA1379
Base silver / billon tetradrachm, possibly of Probus, 276-82Mint of Alexandria, c. 282Reference: BMC Greek Alexandria, c.f. no. 1863.The coin has an irregular flan shape.
Derbyshire. Barro w-upon-Trent. Diocletian. B.M.C. 2530 ; BMC Greek (Alexandria) / Catalogue of the coins of Alexandria and the Nomes (2530, p.326)
Sheffiled Museusm report finding of Tetradrachm in a garden at Woodside
Tetradrachm of Alexandria, struck during the 6th year of the reign of Probus (AD 280-281). Diameter 19.62mm, thickness 3.60mm, weight 6.38g.

A complete copper-alloy tetradrachm of Probus (AD 276-282), dating to the period AD 279-280 (Reece period 14). L ? in fields reverse type depicting eagle standing left, head right. Mint of Alexandria.Obverse: A K M AVP ?POBOC CEB; Laureate, draped and cuirassed bust rightReverse: L ? in fields; Eagle standing left, head rightDiameter: 19.5mm; thickness: 4.0mm. Weight: 6.82g. DA=12:5.A. Geissen, W. Weiser, Katalog Alexandrinischer Kaisermunzen der Sammlung des Instituts fur Altertumskunde der Universitat zu Koln, vol. 4, p. 58, no. 3145.

[A] Shipley boy, Simon Langton, has brought to light the discovery of three Roman coins at Oulton…in the 1930s. These were found by a Mr Nuttal during draining operations, and ultimately came into the collection of Simon's father, Mr Eric Langton, the speedway rider, of 2 Fernhill Rd, Shipley. Simon took the coins to the museum to be identified. Two were found to be bronze tetradrachms, one of Diocletian, 294-295 AD, the other of Maximianus I, 286-295 AD, both minted at Alexandria...the third was bronze quinarius of Constans, 337-350 AD.

[A] Shipley boy, Simon Langton, has brought to light the discovery of three Roman coins at Oulton…in the 1930s. These were found by a Mr Nuttal during draining operations, and ultimately came into the collection of Simon's father, Mr Eric Langton, the speedway rider, of 2 Fernhill Rd, Shipley. Simon took the coins to the museum to be identified. Two were found to be bronze tetradrachms, one of Diocletian, 294-295 AD, the other of Maximianus I, 286-295 AD, both minted at Alexandria...the third was bronze quinarius of Constans, 337-350 AD.

Billon Tetradrachm of Diocletian (284-305) Mint of Alexandria, AD 285-6 Obverse: AK?OVA??IOK?HTIANOCCEB; laureate bust r. Reverse: Eirene (Pax) standing left, holding olive-branch in r. hand and transverse sceptre in left. L - B (= date: 285/6) Reference: BMC Greek, Alexandria, p. 2493var Curtis The Tetradrachms of Roman Egypt p. 164, no. 1976 Milne, Catalogue of Alexandridan Coins, p. 114, no. 4774 The outer edge is unevenly worn. This object was found on the coast at South Shields in the 1890s, where Eastern coins are known from a hoard, possible shipwreck, and as individual finds.
A Roman Provincial copper-alloy tetradrachm of Diocletian (284-305); L E; Eusebia standing left at altar; Alexandria, AD 288-9. BMC Greek, Alexandria, c.f. no. 2510.
A tetradrachm of Maximianus (AD 286-310) found circa 1953 on the north side of St. Thomas’s Street. (Jopling's, according to HER)
Roman coin; copper alloy tetradrachm of Numerian, year 3, AD 284, minted in Alexandria (Milne 4739, Emmett 4022). Diameter 19.14mm, thickness 4.07mm, weight 6.71g.
Possibly tetradrachm of an uncertain emperor, dating to the second half of the 3rd century AD. Possibly mint of Alexandria.
Two denarii of Vespasian; 1 of Geta; 1 copper of Probus (Alexandrian Mint), and others found in Southam.
A base silver tetradrachm of Gallienus, 260-8; L - I? (= Year 13 = AD 265-6); Eagle standing right, wreath in beak; palm behind; Alexandria, AD 265-6. BMC Greek, Alexandria, no. 2236.
Hants. Winchester. 1915. Nero and Poppaea

A Greek and Roman provincial copper-alloy tetradrachm of Carinus dating to the period AD 282 to 285, minted in Alexandria. Reece period 14. Cf. Curtis (1990) Tetradrachms of Roman Egypt, p. 161, no. 1909 passim.Obverse: Laureate head right; AKMAKA [...]Reverse: Eagle standing left, head turned back, wreath in beak, lamda gamma in right hand field; [...]
late Roman copper alloy coin, possibly of Elagabalus? looks similar to Moushmov 633, Markianopolis? The coin has severe copper corrosion and iron staining.
Derbyshire. 'Bullwell (nr. )'. 1926. Maximian. Rev . Elpis, year 2 ; and Diocletian. Rev . Zeus seated, year 3 ? Bullwell is in Notts
Derbyshire. 'Bullwell (nr. )'. 1926. Maximian. Rev . Elpis, year 2 ; and Diocletian. Rev . Zeus seated, year 3 ? Bullwell is in Notts

A bronze coin, issued at Alexandria in the 2nd year of Diocletian's reign (AD 285), dug up at Fishbourne "is not likely to have been current here. Unless lost in recent times it suggests the presence about 300 AD of someone who had been in Egypt". It is slightly worn.
A Greek Imperial billon tetradrachm of Diocletian, minted at Alexandria AD 294/5, regnal year 11 (Reece period 14). Measures 17-18mm, weighs 7.07g, die axis 11, has some wear.Reference: Milne 5158

AE Diocletian Alexandrian Mint (AKS) OYA<> <>OKI (MN) ANOC CEB found in Daniel Street before 1914-18 War. In colln. S.O. FEBEN of Newport, 1938. The present whereabouts of the Feben collection was not ascertainable and no further information was gained.

A base silver (billion) Roman coin; a Roman Provincial tetradrachm of Hadrian. It is 23mm in diameter and 4mm thick. It weighs 11.57gm. It was minted in Alexandria in AD 120 - 121. See the British Museum Coin Catalogue (BMC) Greek Alexandria number 644.

A copper-alloy billon tetradrachma of Claudius II dating to the period AD 268 - 270 (Reece Period 13). Reverse depicts Elpis standing left, holding flower, a long sash hanging from her arm, clutching hem of robe. Mint of Alexandria.Provincial Roman coins of Alexandria are occasionally found in England, and a number are recorded on the Portable Antiquities Scheme database. Such find may be genuine Roman losses, however it could be a modern loss of a souvenir.

A copper alloy Roman provincial billon tetradrachm of Probus (AD 276-82), the reverse depicting an eagle standing left, head right; wreath in beak. The letters L B are to either side. Mint of Alexandria, issued during the second year of his reign (AD 276-7, Reece period 14). BMC Alexandria and the Nomes, p. 315, no. 2427.
Roman copper alloy Tetradrachm of Tacitus (AD 275-276), minted at Alexandria. Reverse type Elpis.
Roman copper alloy tetradrachm of Tacitus, 275-6, Alexandria (BMCG2404).
Hants. Portsmouth or Cosham. 1914. Claudius II. B.M.C. 2308.

A worn copper alloy Roman provincial tetradrachm, probably of Probus and dating to the period AD 276-282. Reece period 14. Mint of Alexandria (Egypt). BMC Greek, Alexandria, p314, cf. 2425-6.
Lincs. Gainsborough (nr.). 1914. Philip I. B.M.C. 1993
A Roman coin, a tetradrachm from Alexandria, of Probus AD 276-82 - MONUMENT NO. 61016 - Lincolnshire Archit Archaeol Soc Reports and Papers 8 NS 1959-60 p17 (DF Petch)

Roman coin of Antoninus Pius, struck in Alexandria in AD149, was found during construction of a new Higher Grade School on West Cliff, Whitby in 1935. The find is now in Whitby Museum. (This is a probable duplication of NZ 81 SE 14).
Tetradrachm of Alexandria, struck during the 5th year of the reign of Probus (AD 279/280).

Lincs. Grantham. 1921. Diocletian. Rev Zeus, year 8

Alexandrian billon tetradrachm of Diocletian (3rd century AD) reputedly found in 1960 by the side of a track off Portsmouth Road. [Near River Wey?]
Bucks. Chesham (site of Roman villa). 1914. Uncertain Emperor, c. 240-50

Tetradrachm of Alexandria, struck during the 4th year of the reign of Maximian (AD 288-289). BMC Alexandria 2596 Coin has little wear or corrosion. Measures 17.6mm diameter by 4.6mm thick. Weight = 8.08g.

Tetradrachm of Alexandria, struck during the second year of the reign of Diocletian, Roma left, AD 285/6. c.f.Copenhagen 1020. Coin is in good condition with little wear or corrosion. Measures 18.5mm diameter by 3.6mm thick. Weight = 6.84g. SNG Copenhagen 975.

Billion Tetradrachm, probably of Diocletian, Mint of Alexandria, Eagle, AD 288/9. Cf. BMC Alexandria 2538. Coin is in good condition, with little corrosion. Measures 18.2mm diameter by 3.7mm thick. Weight = 6.69g.

Copper alloyCoin. Billon Tetradrachm of Diocletian (284-305), Alexandria mint; this coin was kindly identified for the finder by Craig Barclay. Issue of 284-296.Obverse description: Bust laureate right, ?knot behind head.Obverse inscription: [---]ANT.[---]Reverse description: Female figure standing left holding item aloft right and stumping wicket left; symbols or letters lower right field.Diameter: 23.2mm, Weight: 7.83gms, die axis:12

A Roman provincial copper-alloy tetradrachm of Diocletian, mint of Alexandria, Egypt. The reverse depicts Elpis standing left, holding flower, a long sash hanging from her arm, & clutching hem of robe.Provincial Roman coins of Alexandria are occasionally found in England, and a number are recorded on the Portable Antiquities Scheme database, such as NARC-675913. The Metheringham tetradrachm may well be a genuine Roman loss, however it is worth noting that the Lincolnshire regiment served in Egypt at the beginning of the 19th century, and again during World War II, which raises questions as to whether this coin is a modern loss of a souvenir
Herts. Watford. 1920. Valerian. B.M.C. 2142

A Filey fisherman recently discovered near a cliff skip an unmilled copper coin, showing the head of a Roman Emperor, with the Imperial eagle. Mr H. A. Grueber, assistant keeper of the Depertment of coins and medals of the British Museum, to whom it was sent, wrote on Tuesday that though the name of the Emperor is not legible, the coin was struck at Alexandria, in Egypt, about the middle of the third century A.D.

Alexandrian coin; copper alloy tetradrachm, uncertain ruler. Diameter 25.08mm, thickness 4.25mm, weight 10.74g.

Tetradrachm of Alexandria, struck in the 6th year of the reign of Aurelian (AD 274-275). The coin is in good condition, with little wear or corrosion. It measures 18.2mm diameter by 3.7mm thick and weighs 7.22g.

A '2nd brass' of Domitian (AD 81-96) found at Race Hill allotments in 1927; and an Alexandrian type bronze tetradrachm. (1)

An incomplete copper alloy tetradrachm of Carinus (282-5); Lambda Beta (regnal year 2 = 283/4); Elpis standing left holding flower; Alexandria, AD 283/4. PAS notes that gridref seems to be incorrect. Descroed as a field by South Godstone which is by a Roman Road

BUILDING WORKS IN THE BACK GARDEN OF 16 AINSLIE WOOD GARDENS REVEALED AN ALEXANDRIAN TETRADRACHM OF NERO AND POPPEA (C 63-66 AD) AT A DEPTH OF 4 FT (1.23M) BELOW GROUND LEVEL. THE COIN WAS PURCHASED FROM K BARBER BY THE VESTRYHOUSE MUSEUM C 1975.

Alexandrian coin (Tetradrachm) of Maximian I? dated to the late 3rd or 4th century AD. Reference: Catalogue of Alexandrian Coins page 115 Milne: 4828It is unusual for these coins to circulate in Britain and there are a large number now known. One thought is that many of these were brought back from travels to the continent (possibvly during the world wars) and have managed to get into the gardens and fields. However it is possible that they could be a true reflection of travel in the Roman world and have been brought in by Roman soldiers. It is only by the systematic recording of these artefacts that we can identify this trend and either prove or deny its validity.

A TETRADRACHM COIN OF EMPEROR PROBUS C.AD279 MINTED AT ALEXANDRIA FOUND BY MR SCOT IN HIS FRONT GARDEN. [Site of Romano-British settlement. See: https://archaeologydataservice.ac.uk/archsearch/record?titleId=2818180)
Essex. Purfleet. 1929. Uncertain of 3rd. cent. Rev.
Silver Alexandrian tetradrachm of Galba, AD 69.

Tetradrachm of Alexandria. The size and style of the bust suggests that it may be Diocletian. Enharncing the attached images reveals a possible H regnal year (8 = AD 291-292), but this is not clear (Finds Adviser, 01/09/2005).

A copper-alloy Roman provincial billon tetradrachm of Probus (AD 276-282), dating to the period AD 281-282 (Year 7) (Reece period 14). Reverse type depicting an Eagle standing left, head turned right with wreath in beak, flanked by the letters L-Z. Mint of Alexandria. As BMC Alexandria and the Nomes, p. 315, no. 2431.

The findspot where a 3rd century AD Roman coin was found. The coin is a billon tetradrachm of Diocletian (Alexandria Mint) and dates to the second year of his reign, AD 285. It was found at the Tollgate Inn when the A2 was being reconstructed in 1927.
Copper alloy tetradrachm of Alexandria, struck for Probvs (AD 276-82), Eagle right, regnal year 3(277-278 AD).BMC Greek Alexandria 2439Milne 4564

Copper alloy Alexandrian tetradrachm.

Eleven (of very many more) radiates and fourth century bronze coins found on the west side of Breiddin Hill. Some were found around 1865 (probably 1863), while two were presented after the discovery of more in 1910
unspecified Alexandrian coins from from Burnham Overy shown to author

A copper-alloy tetradrachm of Probus minted in Alexandria, Egypt, c.280-281 AD. Reverse: Eagle standing right, wreath in beak, L-S in the field. As BMC Alexandria 2430; Milne 4628.The appearance of this coin (very little patina) is due to it being found in Breckland soils. However, the fact it was found in a garden suggests that it might not be an ancient loss.

A worn copper-alloy Roman provincial tetradrachm of Carinus (AD 282-285), dating to the period AD 282-283 (Reece period 14). Reverse type depicting Tyche standing left holding rudder and cornucopiae, letters LA to the left. Mint of Alexandria. As Geiﬂen and Weiser, 1983: p. 68, nos. 3172-3173; BMC Greek Alexandria, c.f. 2448.Measurements: 20.51mm in diameter, 5.12mm thick and 7.03g in weight.

A copper alloy Alexandrian tetradrachm. 3rd century AD. Diocletian (284-305 AD).Obverse: A K (G)OYA DIOKLHTIANOC CEB (in Greek letters) - Laureate, draped and cuirassed bust right, seen from behind Reverse: Dikaiosyne standing left, holding scales and cornucopiae. L to left; B to right.The B in the right field indicates that this coin was minted in the second year of the emperors reign, and so dating this coin to 285/6 AD. Minted in Alexandria, Egypt.c.f. BMC Alexandria Supplement, no. 3469

indexing.description: Alexandrian Tetradrachms found in Great Britian. Data from a variety of sources.
